Admission Date:  [**2114-4-16**]       Discharge Date:  [**2114-6-15**]

Date of Birth:   [**2079-2-4**]       Sex:  M

Service:  NEUROMEDICINE

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:  Briefly, this is a 35-year-old
man who was admitted on [**2-11**] to the trauma service,
status post resuscitation from a self-inflicted hanging while
the patient was in jail.  He had a prolonged hospital course
on the trauma SICU service, and then the trauma surgery
service on the floor that has been detailed in the previous
discharge summary.  Briefly, his course is notable for
intubation, status post resuscitation, and anoxic brain
injury with injury to the bilateral lentiform nuclei.  He
received a tracheostomy and a percutaneous endoscopic
gastrostomy tube for feeding on [**2114-2-26**].

He was transferred to the neurology service on [**2114-4-16**]
for further care.  He was consulted by the trauma surgery
service for anoxic brain injury, and it was decided that he
should be transferred to the neurology service for further
care.  He had been noted to be very agitated and was started
on Seroquel, as well as Zoloft.  He has now been transferred
to the neurology floor for better control of these movements
and for disposition to a skilled nursing facility.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  Depression.

MEDICATIONS UPON TRANSFER:  1) clonazepam 1 mg po bid, 2)
Seroquel 50 mg po bid, 3) Zoloft 75 mg po qd, 4) bacitracin
ointment 1 application TP [**Hospital1 **], 5) baclofen 10 mg po tid, 6)
bisacodyl 10 mg PR qd, 7) valproic acid 1 gm NG q 12 h, 8)
trazodone 100 mg po q hs prn, 9) labetalol 200 mg po tid, 10)
acetaminophen 325-650 mg po q 4-6 h prn, 11) artificial tears
1-2 drops OU q 3-6 h prn, 12) heparin 5,000 U subcu q 12 h.

ALLERGIES:  No known drug allergies.

SOCIAL HISTORY:  Previously in jail for armed robbery, has
five children, mother is in close contact.

EXAM UPON PRESENTATION:  Generally:  Cachectic male with eyes
open, laying in bed at 30?????? angle, constantly moving.  HEENT:
Reveals moist mucous membranes with trach collar without
purulent secretions.  Lungs:  Clear to auscultation
bilaterally.  Cardiovascular:  Regular rate and rhythm
without murmurs, rubs or gallops.  Abdomen:  Soft, flat,
[**Last Name (LF) 6416**], [**First Name3 (LF) 282**] tube in place without pus or ooze.
Extremities:  No edema or ulcers of the lower extremities.
Neuro - Mental Status:  Eyes open, sticks out tongue, and
closes eyes to command, squeezes fingers and wiggles toes to
command occasionally.  He does not have any verbal output.
Cranial nerves:  Extraocular movements appear grossly intact,
pupils equally round and reactive from 5 to 4 mm bilaterally,
no facial asymmetry, tongue appears midline.  Motor:
Increased tone in all four extremities with slight hypertonia
in the right upper extremity compared to the left.  He is
constantly moving with choreoathetoid movements, more so in
both upper extremities, with some movements noted in the jaw.
His reflexes are brisk and symmetric throughout, biceps,
brachioradialis and patella.  The sensory and gait exam were
not tested.

HOSPITAL COURSE BY PROBLEMS - 1) AGITATION:  His agitation
was thought to be choreoathetoid movements.  He had been on
Dilantin for a question of seizures upon admission to the
trauma SICU and this was eventually changed to depakote at
the end of [**Month (only) 116**] upon admission to the neurology service for
the possibility that they may mitigate his choreoathetoid
movements.  He was continually agitated and required hand
restraints to prevent him from approaching his tracheostomy
and [**Month (only) 282**] tube for accidental removal.  He had an episode on
[**5-28**] in which he had hypoxia by pulse oximetry, as well as
bradycardia by oximetry.  He was attempted to be ventilated
with Ambu bag without much response in his O2 saturation.  He
was briefly admitted to the unit for closer respiratory
monitoring, but he was felt to be back to baseline O2
saturation and heart rate.  There was a question of whether
he had seizure activity during these episodes, as he did
appear very agitated and moving all four extremities
strenuously with what appeared to be episodes of dysregulated
breathing.  He was given parenteral ativan, and his movements
calmed down, and his vital signs returned to [**Location 213**].  He was
transferred back to the neurology floor the same day, on [**5-28**], after he was monitored for a few hours in the unit, and he
had no further episodes that day.

Subsequently, in the two weeks after that brief ICU transfer,
he did have further episodes of bradycardia and hypoxia by
pulse oximetry, but this time these were verified by
auscultation and arterial blood gases which always showed no
evidence of bradycardia or hypoxia by blood gas.  These were
thought to be due partly to malfunctioning oximetry probe
because of his body habitus, as well as some dysregulated
breathing thought to be related to his dyskinetic movements
in the limbs and the respiratory muscles.

To simplify his medication regimen for agitation, he was
slowly tapered off Zoloft which had a slightly activating
affect theoretically.  He was also changed over from depakote
back to Dilantin due to the question of seizure, and he was
loaded quickly with Dilantin on [**5-28**] and continued on
maintenance doses of Dilantin throughout his hospital course.
He also had Haldol added-on prn for agitation and eventually,
by the middle of [**Month (only) 205**], he was started on Haldol standing and
increased to 3 mg NG tid for control of choreoathetoid
movement.  He seemed to tolerate this medication well and was
noted to have fewer spontaneous movements of his upper
extremities.  He was discontinued off his restraints on [**2114-6-13**].  He now apparently is having fewer movements
without any sedation from the Haldol.

2) SEIZURES:  It was never clear that the patient had a
seizure disorder even despite his brain injury.  He had
routine EEGs done but there was never any evidence of
epileptiform discharges.  Episodes during which he would
become extremely agitated, but subsided with benzodiazepines
were not clearly related to seizure activity.  Nevertheless,
he remains on Dilantin for a question of a seizure disorder.
It should also be noted that the Dilantin may potentially
worsen his choreoathetoid movements, but at this time they
are being adequately controlled with the Haldol tid.

3) SECRETIONS:  The patient's tracheostomy tube was inserted
by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] on the surgery service when the patient was
on the trauma surgery service.  He is at chronic risk for
aspiration, and the tracheostomy has been accessed for
allowing for suctioning of the secretions.  On [**6-6**], Dr.
[**Last Name (STitle) **] came by to change the patient's trach tube to a #6
Shiley fenestrated trach tube.  He was tried on multiple
capping trials, but the patient did not tolerate these well,
having transient episodes of hypoxia after the tube was
capped.

ENT was consulted for the possibility of supraglottic
stenosis, and they recommended a trial of steroids after
visualizing supraglottic stenosis on laryngoscopy.  The
patient tolerated the steroids well and actually had
decreased edema by repeat laryngoscopy.  The capping trial
was tried again, but the patient continued to have multiple
secretions, for which a tracheostomy tube was deemed to be
helpful for long-term future for suctioning these secretions.
Therefore, the fenestrated #6 Shiley tracheostomy was left-in
and should probably remain in indefinitely.  He also has had
sputum culture and Gram stain on [**5-21**] which grew out
Pseudomonas, and this was thought likely to be colonization,
as the patient has been afebrile, and there has been no
purulent sputum.

4) TOOTH BLEEDING:  During the second week of [**Month (only) 205**], the
patient did have an episode of bleeding from the mouth.  This
was investigated with a Yankauer suction tube, and it was
thought that the patient's teeth were loose causing him to
bleed slightly.  The bleeding was never major and lost only
maybe 1 or 2 cc at the most.  His bleeding resolved on its
own with two incisor teeth slightly loose, but never caused
any further problems, or never appeared as if they were
infected.

Oral surgery briefly saw the patient informally on [**6-14**]
and felt that a general dentistry consult was necessary.
That dentistry consult is pending depending on whether the
patient is able to leave to rehab where he can get outpatient
dental care.

5) NUTRITION:  The patient has been on tube feeds ever since
the [**Month (only) 282**] tube was placed in [**Month (only) 547**].  His last recorded weight
in [**Month (only) **] was 55 kg, and his last weight on [**6-13**] is 93
pounds.  Nutrition has been closely following him, and he has
been changed on his tube feeds now to 80 cc/h on a new
formula, and he will, from now on, get biweekly weights, so
that he can be monitored for weight loss.  The choreoathetoid
movements were thought to cause increased energy expenditure.
